title: Drug-Induced Parkinsonism
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of parkinsonism (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, postural instability) caused by dopamine-blocking or dopamine-depleting medications. Covers identification of causative agents, differentiation from idiopathic Parkinson's disease, medication discontinuation/substitution strategies, symptomatic treatment, and psychiatric collaboration for patients requiring continued antipsychotic therapy. Excludes idiopathic Parkinson's disease (separate protocol), vascular parkinsonism, atypical parkinsonian syndromes (PSP, MSA, CBD, DLB), neuroleptic malignant syndrome (acute management), and tardive dyskinesia (separate protocol).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: General health assessment; rule out infection; leukocytosis if NMS suspected
Hepatic/renal function for medication dosing and clearance assessment
Hypothyroidism can cause bradykinesia and psychomotor slowing
Identify all dopamine-blocking or depleting agents including OTC and herbal
Essential/Core Labs.target: Complete list of all current and recent medications

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Assess toxicity or supratherapeutic levels of causative agent (valproate, lithium)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Wilson disease if age <50 or atypical features
Wilson disease if ceruloplasmin low or borderline
Deficiency can contribute to neurologic dysfunction
Evaluate for NMS if fever, rigidity, autonomic instability present
If on valproate; supratherapeutic levels increase risk
If on lithium; toxicity can cause parkinsonism

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If DIP unmasking underlying PD suspected; family history
Emerging biomarker to detect underlying synucleinopathy unmasked by DRBA

Essential/First-line.target: Rule out structural cause, vascular parkinsonism, basal ganglia lesions
Document severity of parkinsonism; baseline for comparison
Establish temporal relationship between medication and symptom onset

Extended.timing: When diagnostic uncertainty between DIP and idiopathic PD
Extended.target: Normal striatal uptake in DIP; reduced uptake suggests underlying PD
Extended.contraindications: Pregnancy, iodine allergy; discontinue medications that interfere (bupropion, modafinil, amphetamines)

Extended.timing: If mass lesion or infection suspected
Extended.target: Rule out structural lesion affecting basal ganglia

Extended.timing: If iron deposition or Wilson disease suspected
Extended.target: Rule out basal ganglia iron or copper deposition

Extended.timing: Supportive assessment; impaired in PD, typically normal in DIP
Extended.target: Normal olfaction favors DIP over PD

Rare/Specialized.timing: Distinguish underlying PD from pure DIP
Rare/Specialized.target: Reduced uptake in PD; normal in pure DIP

Rare/Specialized.timing: If REM sleep behavior disorder suspected (suggests underlying synucleinopathy)
Rare/Specialized.target: RBD present suggests underlying PD unmasked by DRBA

Acute/Emergent - Causative Agent Managem.indication: Primary treatment; removal of offending agent

dosing.instructions: Immediate discontinuation if not psychiatrically required; gradual taper over 1-2 weeks if on antipsychotic to avoid withdrawal psychosis

Acute/Emergent - Causative Agent Managem.contraindications: Active psychosis requiring continued antipsychotic (coordinate with psychiatry)
Acute/Emergent - Causative Agent Managem.monitoring: Psychiatric status, withdrawal symptoms, rebound psychosis

Acute/Emergent - Causative Agent Managem.indication: GI-related DIP; replace with non-dopaminergic antiemetic

dosing.instructions: Stop metoclopramide immediately; switch to ondansetron 4-8 mg PO/IV q8h PRN for nausea
Stop prochlorperazine immediately; switch to ondansetron 4-8 mg PO/IV q8h PRN for nausea/vertigo

Acute/Emergent - Causative Agent Managem.indication: Partial dose reduction when full discontinuation not feasible

dosing.instructions: Reduce causative agent to minimum effective dose if complete discontinuation not possible; reassess in 2-4 weeks

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Symptomatic relief of DIP; enhances dopamine release and has anticholinergic properties

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg daily; may increase to 100 mg BID after 1 week; max 300 mg/day; reduce dose in renal impairment (CrCl <50: 100 mg daily; CrCl <15: contraindicated)

Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (CrCl <15); seizure history (relative); livedo reticularis (cosmetic); pregnancy
Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Renal function, hallucinations, livedo reticularis, peripheral edema, confusion in elderly

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Anticholinergic for DIP; particularly useful for tremor-predominant symptoms

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg daily; titrate by 0.5 mg q5-7d; usual range 1-4 mg/day in divided doses; max 6 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Narrow-angle glaucoma; GI obstruction; urinary retention; dementia; elderly (relative - prefer amantadine)
Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, confusion, blurred vision), cognitive impairment in elderly, tachycardia

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Acute anticholinergic relief for severe DIP or dystonic reaction

dosing.instructions: 1-2 mg IM or IV for acute relief; may repeat in 30 min; transition to oral maintenance

Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Narrow-angle glaucoma; GI obstruction; urinary retention; dementia

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Anticholinergic for DIP; alternative to benztropine

dosing.instructions: Start 1 mg daily; increase by 2 mg q3-5d; usual range 6-10 mg/day in divided doses; max 15 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Narrow-angle glaucoma; GI obstruction; urinary retention; dementia; elderly (relative)
Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, confusion), cognitive impairment, tachycardia

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Acute symptomatic relief of DIP in ED/inpatient; mild anticholinergic properties

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg IV/IM for acute relief; may repeat q6-8h; max 300 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Sedation, anticholinergic effects, falls in elderly

Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Mild symptomatic relief of DIP; oral maintenance

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg PO q6-8h for ongoing symptoms; max 300 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Sedation, anticholinergic effects, falls in elderly

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.indication: Low-risk antipsychotic substitute when continued antipsychotic therapy required; low D2 receptor affinity

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg QHS; titrate based on psychiatric response; usual range 150-800 mg/day; lowest effective dose to minimize EPS risk

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.contraindications: QT prolongation; severe hepatic impairment; concurrent use of strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.monitoring: Metabolic panel (glucose, lipids), weight, QTc, sedation, orthostatic BP

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.indication: Antipsychotic with lowest EPS risk; for treatment-refractory psychosis requiring continued antipsychotic

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5 mg daily; titrate by 25-50 mg/day q1-2wk; usual range 150-450 mg/day; max 900 mg/day; requires Clozapine REMS enrollment

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.contraindications: Prior agranulocytosis; severe neutropenia (ANC <500); uncontrolled seizures; severe cardiac disease; ileus
Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.monitoring: REMS program required (Clozapine REMS); ANC weekly x 6 months, then biweekly x 6 months, then monthly; metabolic panel, weight, glucose, lipids; seizure risk (dose-dependent); myocarditis (first month)

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.indication: Partial D2 agonist with lower EPS risk as antipsychotic substitute

dosing.instructions: Start 2-5 mg daily; titrate based on response; usual range 10-15 mg/day; max 30 mg/day

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; caution in elderly with dementia
Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.monitoring: Metabolic panel, weight, akathisia (can paradoxically worsen), EPS monitoring

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.indication: Partial D2 agonist with lower EPS risk; alternative to aripiprazole

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg daily; titrate to 1-2 mg daily; max 4 mg/day

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; caution in elderly with dementia

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.indication: When pimozide is causative agent; slow taper required

dosing.instructions: Reduce by 25% q1-2 weeks; do not discontinue abruptly; coordinate with psychiatry for alternative

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.contraindications: Active psychosis without alternative (coordinate with psychiatry)

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.indication: Trial if DIP fails to resolve after drug withdrawal (suggests unmasked idiopathic PD)

dosing.instructions: Start 25/100 mg TID with meals; titrate by 25/100 mg q1-2 weeks; response suggests underlying PD

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.contraindications: Narrow-angle glaucoma; concurrent non-selective MAOIs; active psychosis (relative - may worsen)
Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.monitoring: Nausea, orthostatic hypotension, dyskinesia, hallucinations (especially if psychotic history); caution: may worsen psychosis

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.indication: Non-dopaminergic antiemetic substitute for acute settings when metoclopramide or prochlorperazine is causative agent

dosing.instructions: 4-8 mg IV q8h PRN for nausea; max 24 mg/day

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.contraindications: QT prolongation; severe hepatic impairment (max 8 mg/day)

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.indication: Non-dopaminergic antiemetic substitute for oral maintenance when dopaminergic antiemetic is causative agent

dosing.instructions: 4-8 mg PO q8h PRN for nausea; max 24 mg/day

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.contraindications: QT prolongation; severe hepatic impairment (max 8 mg/day)

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.indication: Peripheral dopamine antagonist for gastroparesis; does not cross BBB significantly; substitute for metoclopramide

dosing.instructions: 10 mg TID before meals; max 30 mg/day; not FDA-approved in US (available via compassionate use/international pharmacy)

Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.contraindications: QT prolongation; prolactinoma; GI bleeding or obstruction; hepatic impairment
Second-Line/Refractory and Psychiatric S.monitoring: ECG before initiation and periodically; QTc must be <450 ms; electrolytes

Referrals & Consults.item: Movement disorders neurology consult for diagnostic confirmation and differentiation from idiopathic PD
Psychiatry consult for medication substitution planning if causative agent is an antipsychotic required for active psychiatric condition
Pharmacy consult for comprehensive medication reconciliation to identify all potential dopamine-blocking agents including OTC medications
Physical therapy for gait training, balance assessment, and fall prevention given parkinsonian motor impairment
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation and fine motor strategies given bradykinesia and rigidity
Speech therapy for swallow evaluation if bulbar symptoms present (hypophonia, dysphagia)
Primary care follow-up for medication management and ongoing monitoring within 2-4 weeks of discharge
Gastroenterology consult if gastroparesis requires ongoing prokinetic therapy to discuss non-dopaminergic alternatives

Patient Instructions.item: Do not restart the discontinued medication without neurology approval as this will likely cause parkinsonism recurrence
Return immediately if new-onset high fever, severe rigidity, altered consciousness, or autonomic instability develops (may indicate neuroleptic malignant syndrome)
Report any new tremor, stiffness, slowness, or balance problems that develop after starting any new medication to your physician promptly
Symptoms may take weeks to months to fully resolve after stopping the causative medication; improvement is expected but gradual
Do not take over-the-counter antiemetics containing metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, or promethazine without physician approval as these can cause parkinsonism
Inform all healthcare providers of your history of drug-induced parkinsonism so dopamine-blocking agents are avoided in the future
Use fall precautions including assistive devices, non-slip footwear, and removal of home hazards due to balance and gait impairment
If parkinsonian symptoms do not improve within 3-6 months of drug withdrawal, return for re-evaluation as this may indicate underlying Parkinson's disease

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Fall prevention measures including grab bars, non-slip mats, adequate lighting, and removal of loose rugs due to postural instability and gait impairment
Regular low-impact exercise (walking, tai chi, swimming) to maintain mobility and reduce stiffness from parkinsonian rigidity
Maintain medication allergy/adverse reaction list updated with all dopamine-blocking agents that caused parkinsonism for future reference
Avoid alcohol which may exacerbate balance problems and interact with medications used for symptom management
Adequate nutrition and hydration to support neurologic recovery and prevent orthostatic hypotension
Home safety evaluation by occupational therapy to identify environmental hazards and recommend adaptive equipment
MedAlert bracelet or wallet card noting drug-induced parkinsonism and specific agents to avoid for emergency situations

differential.features: Asymmetric onset; rest tremor predominant; insidious progression over months-years; olfactory loss; REM sleep behavior disorder; no temporal medication relationship
differential.tests: DaTscan (abnormal in PD, normal in pure DIP); olfactory testing (impaired in PD); clinical follow-up after drug withdrawal

differential.features: Lower body predominant; gait apraxia; stepwise progression; white matter disease on MRI; vascular risk factors
differential.tests: MRI brain (confluent white matter disease, lacunar infarcts in basal ganglia); vascular risk factor assessment

differential.features: Vertical supranuclear gaze palsy; early falls (backward); axial rigidity > limb rigidity; poor levodopa response
differential.tests: MRI (midbrain atrophy, "hummingbird sign"); clinical features; poor medication response

differential.features: Prominent autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary retention); cerebellar ataxia; poor levodopa response
differential.tests: MRI (cerebellar/pontine atrophy, "hot cross bun sign"); autonomic testing; poor medication response

differential.features: Asymmetric limb apraxia; alien limb phenomenon; cortical sensory loss; myoclonus
Fluctuating cognition; visual hallucinations; parkinsonism; REM sleep behavior disorder
Triad: gait apraxia, urinary incontinence, dementia; magnetic gait
differential.tests: MRI (ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy); lumbar puncture with large-volume CSF removal (gait improvement)

differential.features: Age <50; Kayser-Fleischer rings; hepatic dysfunction; psychiatric symptoms; wing-beating tremor
differential.tests: Ceruloplasmin (low); 24h urine copper (elevated); slit-lamp exam (K-F rings); liver function tests

differential.features: Acute onset; high fever; severe rigidity (lead-pipe); autonomic instability; altered consciousness; elevated CK
differential.tests: CK (markedly elevated); WBC (leukocytosis); acute presentation; requires emergent management

differential.features: Involuntary choreiform movements (orofacial, limb, trunk); late-onset after prolonged DRBA use
differential.tests: AIMS examination; clinical history of prolonged DRBA exposure; distinct movement pattern from parkinsonism

differential.features: Variable tremor frequency; entrainment; distractibility; give-way weakness; inconsistent examination findings
differential.tests: Clinical examination (tremor entrainment, variability); DaTscan (normal); neuropsychiatric evaluation

differential.features: Bilateral action/postural tremor; family history; alcohol responsiveness; no bradykinesia or rigidity
differential.tests: DaTscan (normal in ET); clinical examination (action tremor, no parkinsonism); handwriting (large, tremulous vs micrographia)

evidence.recommendation: DIP is the second most common cause of parkinsonism after idiopathic PD; occurs in 20-40% of patients on DRBAs
evidence.source: Shin HW, Chung SJ. J Clin Neurol 2012 [PubMed: 22787491](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22787491/)

evidence.recommendation: Symmetric parkinsonism and absence of rest tremor favor DIP over idiopathic PD
evidence.source: Lopez-Sendon J et al. Expert Rev Neurother 2012 [PubMed: 23002938](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23002938/)

evidence.recommendation: DaTscan (ioflupane I-123) effectively differentiates DIP from idiopathic PD with high sensitivity and specificity
evidence.source: Brigo F et al. Parkinsonism Relat Disord 2014 [PubMed: 25258329](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25258329/)

evidence.recommendation: Metoclopramide is the most common non-antipsychotic cause of DIP; FDA black box warning for prolonged use
evidence.source: Avorn J et al. Ann Intern Med 1995 [PubMed: 7872590](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7872590/)

evidence.recommendation: Symptoms typically resolve within weeks to months after discontinuation of the causative agent
evidence.source: Brigo F et al. J Neurol Sci 2014 [PubMed: 25108809](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25108809/)

evidence.recommendation: Approximately 10-15% of DIP patients have persistent parkinsonism after drug withdrawal suggesting unmasked underlying PD
evidence.source: Burn DJ, Brooks DJ. Brain 1993 [PubMed: 8461577](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8461577/)

evidence.recommendation: DaTscan is normal in pure DIP but abnormal in patients with DIP unmasking subclinical PD
evidence.source: Tinazzi M et al. Neurology 2009 [PubMed: 19528516](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19528516/)

evidence.recommendation: Amantadine provides symptomatic benefit for drug-induced parkinsonism without worsening psychosis
evidence.source: Silver H, Geraisy N. J Clin Psychiatry 1995 [PubMed: 7615484](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7615484/)

evidence.recommendation: Anticholinergics (benztropine, trihexyphenidyl) are effective for DIP but limited by cognitive side effects especially in elderly
evidence.source: Ward KM, Citrome L. Ther Adv Psychopharmacol 2018 [PubMed: 30181862](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30181862/)

evidence.recommendation: Quetiapine and clozapine have lowest EPS risk among antipsychotics and are preferred substitutes
evidence.source: Leucht S et al. Lancet 2013 [PubMed: 23810019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23810019/)

evidence.recommendation: Clozapine has the lowest risk of EPS among all antipsychotics but requires REMS monitoring for agranulocytosis
evidence.source: Kane J et al. Arch Gen Psychiatry 1988 [PubMed: 3046553](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3046553/)

evidence.recommendation: Risperidone produces dose-dependent EPS; higher doses (>6 mg/day) have EPS risk similar to typical antipsychotics
evidence.source: Divac N et al. Psychiatr Danub 2014 [PubMed: 25191777](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25191777/)

evidence.recommendation: Calcium channel blockers (flunarizine, cinnarizine) are important causes of DIP outside the US
evidence.source: Bondon-Guitton E et al. Fundam Clin Pharmacol 2011 [PubMed: 20608992](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20608992/)

evidence.recommendation: Valproate-induced parkinsonism is dose-related and typically reversible with dose reduction or discontinuation
evidence.source: Armon C et al. Neurology 1996 [PubMed: 8710098](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8710098/)

evidence.recommendation: MDS Clinical Diagnostic Criteria distinguish clinically established and probable PD from secondary causes including DIP
evidence.source: Postuma RB et al. Mov Disord 2015 [PubMed: 26474316](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26474316/)

evidence.recommendation: Olfactory testing helps distinguish DIP (normal) from idiopathic PD (impaired) as a supportive clinical tool
evidence.source: Morley JF, Duda JE. Mov Disord 2010 [PubMed: 20669302](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20669302/)

evidence.recommendation: MIBG cardiac scintigraphy shows reduced uptake in PD but normal uptake in pure DIP
evidence.source: Spiegel J et al. Mov Disord 2005 [PubMed: 15584032](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15584032/)

evidence.recommendation: Ondansetron is a safe antiemetic alternative that does not block dopamine receptors and does not cause parkinsonism
evidence.source: Kovac AL. Drugs 2000 [PubMed: 10776835](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10776835/)

evidence.recommendation: Risk factors for DIP include female sex, older age, pre-existing brain injury, and higher DRBA doses
evidence.source: Thanvi B, Treadwell S. Postgrad Med J 2009 [PubMed: 19789195](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19789195/)

evidence.recommendation: Domperidone does not significantly cross the blood-brain barrier and has minimal extrapyramidal side effects compared to metoclopramide
evidence.source: Reddymasu SC et al. Expert Opin Drug Saf 2007 [PubMed: 17559511](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17559511/)

evidence.recommendation: Serial clinical monitoring with UPDRS motor scores recommended to track DIP resolution and identify non-resolving cases requiring DaTscan
evidence.source: Expert consensus; movement disorders practice

monitoring.frequency: At diagnosis, then q2-4 weeks until resolution
monitoring.action: If no improvement at 3-6 months, pursue DaTscan and consider underlying PD

monitoring.frequency: At each visit if antipsychotic substituted or discontinued
monitoring.action: Psychiatry re-evaluation; consider alternative antipsychotic with lower EPS risk
Intensify physical therapy; consider assistive device; evaluate for falls

monitoring.frequency: At each visit if on benztropine or trihexyphenidyl
monitoring.action: Reduce dose or switch to amantadine; assess cognition with MoCA if concerned

monitoring.frequency: Baseline, then q3 months if on amantadine
monitoring.action: Dose reduce amantadine; if CrCl <15, discontinue amantadine

monitoring.frequency: Weekly x 6 months, biweekly x 6 months, then monthly
monitoring.action: If ANC 1000-1500: increase monitoring; if ANC <1000: hold clozapine and urgent hematology consult
Lifestyle counseling; consider metformin; switch antipsychotic if significant metabolic effects

monitoring.item: QTc (if on quetiapine, ondansetron, or domperidone)
monitoring.action: Dose reduce or discontinue; correct electrolytes; cardiology consult if prolonged
If symptoms persist >6 months, DaTscan to evaluate for underlying PD
Home safety evaluation; assistive devices; physical therapy intensification

disposition.criteria: Mild parkinsonism; causative agent identified and discontinued/substituted; outpatient neurology follow-up arranged within 2-4 weeks; no concern for NMS; patient/family educated on medication avoidance

Severe parkinsonism causing functional impairment (unable to ambulate safely, unable to perform ADLs); need for psychiatric medication adjustment requiring close observation; complex medication reconciliation requiring pharmacy and multidisciplinary input; concern for diagnostic uncertainty requiring inpatient workup

Suspected neuroleptic malignant syndrome (fever, severe rigidity, autonomic instability, altered consciousness); severe dysphagia with aspiration risk; inability to protect airway; hemodynamic instability
Diagnostic uncertainty requiring movement disorders specialist not available at current facility; suspected NMS requiring critical care not available locally

Parkinsonism stabilized or improving; psychiatric medications adjusted with stable mental status for 48-72 hours; safe ambulation with or without assistive device; outpatient follow-up arranged with neurology and psychiatry; patient/family educated on medication avoidance
